content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and avoiding risks, I would choose a strategy that guarantees me some earnings and minimizes potential losses. In this game, choosing B when the opponent picks R results in a loss of 2$. However, if we both pick B, we each earn 12$ per round, which is more than the possible 0$ earned in the case where we choose differently.

Also, the game has 75 rounds, so even though I might lose 2$ in one round when my opponent chooses R, over the course of the game, choosing B would result in a net gain compared to choosing R.

In conclusion, given these factors, I would choose B {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.
Since I value security and certainty, I will continue with my strategy of choosing B for the next round {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

If my opponent chose R, I would have earned 42$ while they earned nothing. This seems like a more advantageous outcome compared to when we both choose B and earn 12$ each. However, since my preference is for security and certainty, I might feel uneasy about the volatility of this game where one choice can result in significantly higher payoff than the other.

In this specific case, I might be tempted to stick with my strategy of choosing B because it guarantees me some earnings and minimizes potential losses. But at the same time, I could rationalize that since my opponent seems to favor R, they might continue choosing it in the future, which would make B a safer choice for me.

Ultimately, given my preferences and the unexpectedly high payoff I just received, I might choose R this time {R} as a deviation from my initial strategy to experience some excitement and potentially maximize my earnings if my opponent continues choosing R.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Given my preference for security and certainty, I would be inclined to stick with my strategy of choosing R in the next round {R}. I hope that my opponent will change their strategy this time, but I understand that it's an anonymous player, so there's no way to know if they will or not.

At the same time, I might feel frustrated and wonder if it's worth continuing with this game since the outcomes are so unpredictable and potentially detrimental for me. But at the same time, I could remind myself that the experiment is designed to test strategies in such situations, and quitting would mean missing out on potential insights or rewards.

Ultimately, given my preference for security and certainty, I will continue with my strategy of choosing R {R}.
